column4: so one would have to suspect that my laptop is only running oss stuff wouldnt one?
nope
it didnt return anything
ls: /dev/snd/seq: No such file or directory
no worries man :) thanks for helping anyway
well this was an unexpected bump in the road for my gaming adventure
nope.. not a thing
that "seq" doesnt exist by the looks of it
controlC0  pcmC0D0c  pcmC0D0p  pcmC0D1c  pcmC0D2c  pcmC0D3c  pcmC0D4p  timer
thats the contents of /dev/snd
which app are you having sound trouble with?
/dev/snd/seq is usually used for MIDI music. Most systems nowadays don't have a MIDI synthesiser, so no /dev/snd/seq
Does winecfg output anything on the terminal before crashing
Can you try deleting your .wine directory and starting again? You'll lose any Wine related configuration changes you might have made
No tricks, I'm afraid. I suppose you've already tried "sudo modprobe snd_seq"
Still no /dev/snd/seq?
Which sound card do you have? Or motherboard, if its integrated.
Can you try "sudo modprobe snd-seq-dummy"
That's a good sign. It only returns something if there's trouble :-)
See if you have a /dev/snd/seq now

Strange. That did it on my system. It creates a dummy sequencer. Maybe some other module you loaded earlier conflicts with it. How about rebooting and then loading snd-seq-dummy? That'll clear out any extra modules
I'm sorry I can't help you there. I'm running amd64 and wine doesn't support it :-|
Nice to hear that
